Suetonius asserted that Caligula had men sawn in half and the tongue of an equestrian excised before he was thrown back to the beasts, see Suetonius, Lives of the Caesars
the ‘Twelve Tables’ allowed creditors to cut an insolvent debtor’s body into pieces and each take a share, see Max Radin, ‘Secare Partis: the Early Roman Law of Execution Against a Debtor’
